H0.text: Loss of thermal stability is the characteristic of a cold‑water upwelling near the coast of Northern California that results in a large concentration of marine organisms.

H1.text: High nutrient concentration is the characteristic of a cold‑water upwelling near the coast of Northern California that results in a large concentration of marine organisms.

H2.text: Consistent surface-current flow rate is the characteristic of a cold-water upwelling near the coast of Northern California that results in a large concentration of marine organisms.

H3.text: Increased availability of dissolved oxygen is the characteristic of a cold‑water upwelling near the coast of Northern California that results in a large concentration of marine organisms.

A4.text: The cold water is highly productive due to the upwelling, which brings to the surface nutrient-rich sediments, supporting large populations of whales, seabirds and important fisheries.

A5.text: Phytoplankton production is dramatically increased in these areas because the nutrient-rich water lying below the pycnocline is relatively close to the surface and is thus easily upwelled.
